Untitled(1)
						ðŸ”—
					
					16:20:14 on 2022-10-26
					
				
					Been doing a bunch of stuff around the house,
					and for school. Emacs has been a constant source
					of tinkering that I can do inbetween sessions of
					work. Not to mention that I can write my papers in
					it, too. Double-win! Aside from that, I'm just
					trying to work with my wife to get my parents into
					the established "groove" down here. So far so
					good, but there is more to work on.
					School has been a big shit-show of admins not
					being able to create an online class for my
					Capstone, not having a professor for the first day
					of class and generally just fucking up everything
					that can be fucked up. I'm so checked out that I'm
					probably better off just asking them to refund my
					money. Not that helps me get closer
					to actually graduating. Sigh.
					I'm exhausted, from trying to lose weight,
					exercising in my company's gym, to just trying to
					keep up with everything going on in the world. I
					find myself low on empathy and high on burn out.
					It would be nice if I could just take a couple of
					days to nap or get shit straightend out with my
					health and/or school. I don't see that one coming
					anytime soon, though.

Downscaling my Emacs Package Usage
						ðŸ”—
					
					20:25:47 on 2022-10-19
				
				
					Emacs packages are all well good. There are
					lots of tools to allow you to extend Emacs in ways
					that were likely never imagined when it was
					created (checks notesâ€¦ 46
					years ago). Some of these are
					tremendously useful, worthy of inclusion into
					Emacs proper. Some are just utilities to make a
					particular task easier or smooth over a rough
					edge.
					I, however, I don't use many of those things. I
					don't program anymore, and many of those utility
					packages just sort of paper over some
					functionality that I could likely just figure out
					on my own, or eschew altogether. To that end, I've
					been stripping out parts of my Emacs configuration
					or rewriting it to not require things
					like use-package or writing more
					functions that do similar functionality. One big
					thing is investigating the inner workings of the
					core distribution of Emacs. Just like I've been
					doing some archaeology in previous posts, I've
					been putting some of the things I've discovered to
					use. Things like configuring ibuffer
					to have custom categories, or
					attaching hl-line to make
					navigating dired-like buffers easier
					instead of using something like lin.
					It's been a journey, and a learning experience,
					but I think I'm more in tune with how to use Emacs
					more effectively, even with those
					enhancements.

Tailscaling My Network
						ðŸ”—
					
					16:13:59 on 2022-10-14
				
				
					Well, I'm going to give it a shot.
					Tailscale has given me hope that I can allow my
					wife to access our NAS from anywhere, and a hope
					for me that I can stop using third-party VPN
					solutions (like the excellent Mullvad VPN
					service -- not paid advertising, btw). The best
					part is that I can get this service for relatively
					cheap, if not free. Not that I'm not willing to
					pay for the service, I absolutely am, it's just
					they're running a plan that gets you what I need
					just by having a free GitHub organization.
					While GitHub and Tailscale are not my favorite
					"free" (as-in-beer) platforms, I'm relatively
					comfortable with having both on those plans and
					not having my data relentlessly harvested
					for advertising data (which I will block).

She-Hulk Smashes the 4th Wall (and Matt Murdock)
						ðŸ”—
					
					13:04:38 on 2022-10-13
				
				
					The season finale of She-Hulk was completely
					amazing. So many call outs, so much fresh
					storytelling. K.E.V.I.N.!
					I cannot wait until next season. Though I know
					that the weekly epsiodes for Disney+ are basically
					done for the year. Which, while sad, is good
					because I'm sure the wait will be worth it.

Web Metrics Considered Harmful (Generally)
						ðŸ”—
					
					20:48:02 on 2022-10-10
				
				
					Man, it's fun to look at metrics. It lets you
					know that you're doing well (or not) and how you
					might be able to improve. These improvements
					usually help ensure your visitors get excellent
					experiences when visiting your site. Except for
					me, because I don't run a big website with
					complicated parts and massive payloads with CDNs
					and megabytes of JavaScript. I have a single HTML
					page with some external images (hosted here) and a
					very small CSS file, a tiny amount of
						non-essential javascript tops it all off.
					Which is why stuff like this makes me feel like
					the whole thing is just more of that synthetic
					benchmark bullshit that we get fed for every other
						thing we try and compare.
					
						
							
							
							For such a simple site, why do I not get a perfect score?
						
						For such a simple site, why do I not get a perfect score?

Temptations
						ðŸ”—
					
					11:00:37 on 2022-10-10
				
				
					
						
							
							
							Sometimes, I have to remind myself that I don't need anything fancier than simple HTML
						
						Sometimes, I have to remind myself that I don't need anything fancier than simple HTML
					
					I come across news about the "Fediverse" from
					time-to-time, while not being involved in it
					anymore. At various points in my past, I was
					trying to map my blog onto the mechanisms that run
					that system, as well as be a good "IndieWeb"
					citizen. Back then, I was using tooling that
					wasn't quite there yet. Trying to map tooling like
					WordPress into paradigms that it wasn't really
					desiged (at the core) to handle seems to be the
					favorite past-time of web-developers. I also was
					looking at dedicated platforms, like micro.blog
					and Known. Those are good in their own right. Just
						not for me.
					Today I came across a couple more dedicated
					packages for being both personal microblog
					services, and good IndieWeb citizens.
					Microblog.pub and Akkoma. Great ideas for ensuring
					that your content hits the widest community it
					can, and provides nice feedback and other "cool
					social" stuff, like "likes, favorites and
					reblogs". It's really a tempting time to spin up
					something and see if things have improved over the
						time I've been absent from the space.
					That's the thing, though. I don't need
					those things. I don't want the hassle of
					managing postgres, or python, or elixr or any of
					the other components required to bundle something
					that I likely wont get any use out of anyway. I
					already know that no one will use it,
					that I won't like managing it and that it'll all
					end in frustration. I'm trying not to be that guy
					anymore. I just want to slam some text into a
					document and save it. Until I find some growing
					pain that I can't fix, this is all I need.

Link:
						
							The Expert vs the Impostor
						
					
					08:55 on 2022-05-03
				
				
					Woof, Impostor Syndrome. Story of my life.
					I spent nearly ten years working on websites and doing
					"coding" (for whatever values of that you're willing to
					accept for writing 
					PHP). This was a position I inherited
					because I had tinkered with it as a kid and had an affinity
					for it. I was far from being a professional.
					I often have to remind myself that I am not:
					
						A developer
						An artist or creative type
						A systems engineer
					
					I have an expertise in doing desktop support. That's
					pretty much it. Everything else is just me learning enough
					to be, as Kev puts: "dangerous". I sometimes think that
					everyone behaves this way, and no one is a expert. However,
					that is clearly not the case. People may not know every
					aspect of a thing they have expertise in. However, for all
					intents and purposes, they're an 'expert'. I just wish I
					knew where the line was.
				
				ðŸ”— Permalink to this post.

Link:
						
							Better Blocker Forgotten
						
					
					11:53 on 2022-04-11
				
				
					What an absolute tool. I don't even know why I bother with
						anything Aral has to say. He's such a blowhard, spinning up
						projects that he has no intention of finishing, or even
						supporting when he's bored of it. I guess this is a "shame on
						me" moment.
					Not 3 years ago, Aral was talking
							about how their iOS ad-blocking app "Better Blocker" was doing
							middlingly well, but gave them a decent chunk of change a
						year (more than some make doing actual jobs). Now,
						because Apple didn't fight doing searches for child pornography
						on people's photos, they've taken it down.
					Mind you, Better Blocker was a paid appliction. One
						that required only maintenance to stay in line with the app
						store rules and to throw up block list updates on some external
						server. Not exactly rocket science. When they took down their
						app, they didn't even bother to tell paid users. It just stops
						updating. The app page is unavailable and there is nothing but a
						blog post on his personal site about it. Wonderful.
					What a pretentious douchebag. If you want to steer clear of
						non-profits doing more harm than good, then stay away from the
						so-called "Small Technology Foundation". Nothing good comes from
						either of these two grifters using the guise of non-profit to
						live a privleged life..
				
				ðŸ”— Permalink to this post.
